liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government says coins featuring King Charles III will be released before the end of this year. The Royal Mint produced six effigies of Queen Elizabeth II on Australian currency during her 70-year reign. Assistant Treasury Minister Andrew Leigh says developing a new coin is a long process. "There's a range of things we need to get right, the mint's dyes need to be appropriately tested, each of the dyes need to sustain some 200-to-300,00 coin printings, so all of that testing process is in place," he said. "I'm keen to make sure we get a lot of those new coins out. I know for the vast majority of Australians this will be the first time they hold a coin that has a King and not a Queen on it, so it's a big moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Expect to see King Charles on your coins before the year ends

children.content: The federal government says coins featuring
King Charles
III
will be released before the end of this year.

props.alt: A blank coin for a portrait of King Charles side profile.

children.content: The first coins bearing the image of King Charles were revealed last September.
(AP: Alastair Grant)
The Royal Mint produced six effigies of
Queen Elizabeth
II
on Australian currency during her 70-year reign.
Assistant Treasury Minister
Andrew Leigh
says developing a new coin is a long process.

"There's a range of things we need to get right, the mint's dyes need to be appropriately tested, each of the dyes need to sustain some 200-to-300,00 coin printings, so all of that testing process is in place," he said.

"I'm keen to make sure we get a lot of those new coins out. I know for the vast majority of Australians this will be the first time they hold a coin that has a King and not a Queen on it, so it's a big moment."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Actor David McCallum, who became a teen heart-throb in the hit series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. in the 1960s and was the eccentric medical examiner in the popular NCIS 40 years later, has died. He was 90. McCallum died on Monday of natural causes surrounded by family at New York Presbyterian Hospital, TV network CBS said in a statement. "David was a gifted actor and author, and beloved by many around the world. He led an incredible life, and his legacy will forever live on through his family and the countless hours on film and television that will never go away," the network said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: David McCallum, star of NCIS, dies at 90

featuredLink.title: David McCallum, star of hit TV series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. and NCIS, dies at 90

children.content: David McCallum in 2013.
(Reuters: Fred Prouser/file)
Actor
David McCallum,
who became a teen heart-throb in the hit series The Man From U.N.C.L.E.
in the 1960s and was the eccentric medical examiner in the popular NCIS
40 years later, has died. He was 90.
McCallum died on Monday of natural causes surrounded by family at New York Presbyterian Hospital, TV network CBS said in a statement.
"David was a gifted actor and author, and beloved by many around the world. He led an incredible life, and
his legacy will forever live on through his family and the countless hours on film and television
that will never go away," the network said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Senate inquiry into the decision to block more Qatar Airways flights into Australia reconvenes today in Brisbane. Bridget McKenzie, the Shadow Minister for Transport, spoke to News Breakfast a little earlier and says the "end result" for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder will be "a matter for shareholders." "But I think to the pilots' points, Qantas as a corporate citizen has not covered itself in glory in recent past," she said. "We have seen their former CEO set up a scheme for a very, very cosy retirement. "We have seen Qantas, and the Qantas group more broadly including Jetstar, trying to keep over $500 million of their own customers' money through those COVID flight credits. "We have seen the High Court deem that they illegally sacked 1,700 workers and the ACCC is taking them to court over ghost flights. "So on any marker, they are not behaving as we'd expect a corporate citizen to in this country and that's something for shoulders to deal with."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bridget McKenzie says Qantas chairman's 'end result' up to shareholders

children.content: A Senate inquiry into the decision to block more Qatar Airways flights into Australia reconvenes today in Brisbane.

props.alt: Bridget speaks in a studio with the Brisbane skyline behind her.

"So on any marker,
they are not behaving as we'd expect a corporate citizen to
in this country and that's something for shoulders to deal with."

image.altText: Brisbane Lions player Lachie Neale smiles while standing behind a podium with the Brownlow Medal on a screen behind him.

props.synopsis: Ten years after playing in his first grand final, Lachie Neale is preparing for a second with a completely different game that has put him in lofty heights as a two-time Brownlow medallist.

title.children: Lachie Neale joins an elite club with his second Brownlow Medal. Here's how he did it

title.children: Wall Street snaps four-day losing streak, ASX to open flat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's richest person Gina Rinehart has spent another $132 million to up her strategic stake in lithium explorer (and takeover target) Liontown Resources. Liontown is currently the subject of a $6.6 billion takeover bid by US chemicals giant Albemarle. It's possible that Ms Rinehart's intervention could force Albermarle to amend its bid for the Western Australian lithium explorer. How much does Rinehart own? Ms Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting group now controls 235.5 million shares in Liontown (or 10.69% of the company). That's a significant increase from a fortnight ago – when Liontown revealed that Ms Rinehart controlled almost 170 million shares (or 7.7% of the company). Over the past two weeks, Ms Rinehart's company has been buying Liontown shares (at $3 per share). Albemarle is about half-way through its one-month period of exclusive due diligence – scrutinising the progress at Liontown's factility at Kathleen Valley (which is still under construction). Liontown said it would start producing lithium in around nine months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gina Rinehart increases stake in lithium company Liontown Resources

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It seems Qantas just can't catch a break. The latest in this slow-motion train wreck is that pilots are calling for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to step down. This is the first time such a call has been made by the Australian and International Pilots Association (AIPA). In a statement, the association said it had written to Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson to inform her of the pilots' position. "Richard Goyder has overseen one of the most damaging periods in Qantas history which has included the illegal sacking of 1,700 workers, allegations of illegally marketing cancelled flights, and a terribly managed return to operations after Covid-19," AIPA president Tony Lucas said. "The morale of Qantas pilots has never been lower. We have totally lost confidence in Goyder and his Board. "Qantas desperately needs a culture reset but how can this happen with Richard Goyder as chairman? "Despite overseeing the destruction of the Qantas brand, Goyder last week accepted a near $100,000 pay rise — taking his pay to $750,000 — while staff are expected to accept a two-year wage freeze. This is a galling and tone-deaf decision."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pilots call for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to step down

children.content: It seems Qantas just can't catch a break. The latest in this slow-motion train wreck is that pilots are calling for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to step down.
This is the
first time such a call has been made by
the Australian and International Pilots Association (AIPA).
In a statement, the association said it had written to Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson to inform her of the pilots' position.

"Richard Goyder has overseen one of the most damaging periods in Qantas history which has included the illegal sacking of 1,700 workers, allegations of illegally marketing cancelled flights, and a terribly managed return to operations after Covid-19," AIPA president Tony Lucas said.
"The morale of Qantas pilots has never been lower. We have totally lost confidence in Goyder and his Board.
"Qantas desperately needs a culture reset but how can this happen with Richard Goyder as chairman?

"Despite overseeing the destruction of the Qantas brand, Goyder last week accepted a near $100,000 pay rise — taking his pay to $750,000 — while staff are expected to accept a two-year wage freeze. This is a galling and tone-deaf decision."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's latest finance news. The Australian share market is likely to have a flat (or slightly weaker) start to the trading day, with ASX futures down 0.1%. However, it could rise as the day progresses, given Wall Street ended its day with modest gains (after dropping sharply for the past four days). In contrast, European markets fell moderately, including Britain's FTSE (-0.8%), Germany's DAX (-1%) and the Stoxx 600 (-0.6%). The Australian dollar was marginally lower at 64.2 US cents. The US greenback, meanwhile, rose to its highest in almost 10 months against a basket of currencies after the US Federal Reserve last week signalled it may have to lift interest rates further — and was likely to hold them higher for longer than investors had expected. Here's how one market analyst decribed the situation to the Reuters news agency. There is a "tug of war between investors seemingly getting more concerned about 'higher for longer' ... and bulls wondering maybe we have seen the correction and we can start to build from these levels higher," said Chuck Carlson, chief executive at Horizon Investment Services. Over the past few weeks, share market investors have been feeling unnerved by what's happening in the bond market. There's been a sell-off in government bonds, causing their prices to fall and interest rates (or yields) to rise. One of the most closely-watched benchmarks, the US 10-year Treasury yield, climbed 10 basis points to 4.54% (on exectations rates will remain higher for longer). This is its highest level since 2007, just before the global financial crisis.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX likely to open flat as US Treasury yields hit 16-year high
